results.title: Mamie & Maggie
results.creator_credit: Eulea Kiraly, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Eulea Kiraly pays tribute to her grandmothers Maggie and Mamie, who are a source of comfort, inspiration and resilience. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Tuggeranong Arts Centre.

results.title: Fire of time
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Urban development in Barcelona has all but destroyed the once vibrant Barrio Chino where the nights were days and the days were long. This is an evocative film shot through windows, on street corners and in small rooms. People, clouds, and the swift tail lights of cars glide past and through, as fleeting traces of the passage of time. And as this one working-class Red Light district is transformed and changed by the process of gentrification, the former residents appear as ghosts, their prescence - as graffiti, as shadows - a reminder of the real history of the city. Larger forces cause buildings and neighbourhoods to vanish but they are rebuilt again in memories, worn photographs and in light. Adam Cohen’s handling of light gives people the substance of phantoms and their passages through the half deserted streets evoke Eliot, Proust, and Chris Marker. Sounds of this world are orchestrated with cello, organ and guitar to form a profoundly beautiful work about memory, longing and loss.

results.title: In a galaxy far far away  - me and my game
results.brief_description: Born and raised in Mildura, 15 year old Justyn Smith loves to play video games. It keeps him out of trouble and besides roaming around the streets of Mildura is boring anyway! This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Koorie Heritage Trust.

results.title: Heaven
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Surfing, sexuality and masculine bodies beneath the female gaze. A handheld camera closes in on private space of surfers as they disrobe in carparks and attempts to catch them ‘out’. Filmed in and around Sydney beaches, Moffatt and female friends have documented a playful but edgey representation of surfer culture as the interaction between the filmmaker and subject moves towards active voyerism. The heavy drum beats and lapping waves of the soundtrack mirror the thrill and excitement of gender mis-representation. How do the males react, or perform, on camera and how do audiences interpret their own voyeuristic desires? What does it suggest about the role of the film maker, of ethics or ‘surveillance’?

constellations_other.name: Flipping the gaze (Placeholder)
constellations_other.description: Steven Rhall's Avert considers how the white gaze has been trained on First Peoples and flips the surveillance by turning the camera on the viewer.

results.title: New life new country
results.creator_credit: Fatma Coskun, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Fatma Coskun came from a small village amongst the mountains of Corun. However, financial hardships drove her and her husband to Australia to start a new life. Despite a major setback at the beginning of their journey, Fatma and her family consider themselves very fortunate to have settled in Australia.
